Award.AwardTitle: Geometry and Mechanics of Nonthermal Packings
Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
The proposed experiments are designed to probe on the same footing, the structure, linear response and failure of assemblies of (a) compact grains, (b) extended one-dimensional filaments, and (c) two-dimensional sheets. Since the elements in these packings are macroscopic, the packings are nonthermal, and are therefore far from equilibrium. The award contributes to understanding whether untargeted packing protocols lead to final states with statistically reproducible properties. The proposed experiments will study the three-dimensional structure of model systems of each type. At the same time, forces of shear and compression will be applied to probe the mechanical strength of the material. Simultaneously, small loads will be applied to characterise the linear response. The spatial elements that bestow rigidity on a material are often most clearly exposed by studying how the material fails under external loading, so loads large enough to generate yielding will also be imposed. The proposed work gives graduate and undergraduate students exposure to a variety of techniques and the opportunity to work in newly-emerging areas of physics. The PI is also an organizer of an annual summer school hosted at UMass Amherst for early-career graduate students in soft matter physics.

****Non-Technical Abstract****
The mechanical properties and structure of assemblies of large particles are much more poorly understood than that of assemblies of molecules or atoms. The proposed work will study three geometrically different classes of these systems: (1) Granular materials which range from range from pharmaceutical powders to mineral ores, and from food grains to the soils they grow in. (2) Fibrous materials are the main constituent of plant matter, as well of human products ranging from paper to fabrics and insulants. (3) Crumpled sheets appear in flowers and leaves, as well as in trash compaction and shock absorption. The goal is to study idealized versions of these systems by 3-dimensional imaging techniques that allow the structure to be visualized while forces are applied to the material. This will give important clues as to the structural elements in these materials that are responsible for their mechanical properties. The proposed work gives graduate and undergraduate students exposure to a variety of techniques and the opportunity to work in newly-emerging areas of physics. The PI is also an organizer of an annual summer school hosted at UMass Amherst for early-career graduate students in soft matter and statistical physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mechanical properties and structure of assemblies of large objects are much more poorly understood than that of assemblies of molecules or atoms. This grant enabled us to study three geometrically distinct classes of such materials – sheets, filaments and grains.

We studied thin sheets placed under a variety of different conditions to understand the patterns they take on.  (Image Panel A) When they are compressed, or subjected to nonuniform tension, or forced to drape along a curved surface, they tend to wrinkle or fold up. One of the major outcomes of this project is that we achieved a unified understanding of the wavelength of wrinkle patterns. This “local lambda law” that we proposed and tested, applies in very general circumstances and will be of value in generating wrinkles to pattern surfaces, or in using wrinkles to measure material properties. We also studied highly-crumpled sheets, and discovered that a crumpled ball that we are familiar with from our daily experience with paper or fabric, has a subtle but strong underlying order. This will inform the use of crumpled materials for shock absorption, vibration isolation, and as a space-filling structure.

We have studied the properties of thin filaments in order to understand their shapes, and how they recover from being deformed into highly-curved configurations. (Image Panel B)  A simple example involves curving a thin fibre till its ends meet, and then releasing it. This relaxation of a filament has been studied in the context of biologically important examples like cilia and flagella which microbes and cells use for locomotion, but the common situation of large curvature had not previously been addressed. We discovered that the motions of even highly-curved filaments can be described quite simply in terms of their flexural rigidity, and the properties of the medium they are in. Apart from the natural contexts to which this applies, we have also proposed using this result as a way to measure mechanical properties of liquid surfaces.

We have used model granular media made up of square tiles as an example of how macroscopic particles may be used to successfully model the behaviour of microscopic rigid shapes. (Image Panel C)  We have established that as denser and denser packings of squares are created, the squares first start off in completely disordered configurations (like a fluid) and then start orienting similarly (like a liquid crystal) and finally form a crystalline pattern like the squares on a chess-board. In this funding period, we also found methods to modify granular particles so that they would move in chosen directions when vibrated, without changing their overall shape. This is of potential value in controlling flows of granular matter.

Finally, we have exposed several graduate and undergraduate students, and a high school student to research in this period. Two graduate students completed the PhD degree and one an MS degree in this period. We also ran summer schools for graduate students across the US, and helped with a summer workshop for middle school teachers.
